description: x such that y^2=C(x,0)+C(x,1)+C(x,2)+C(x,3) is soluble.
comments: n such that A000125(n) is a perfect square. - _Frank M Jackson_, Mar 13 2013
references: R. K. Guy, Unsolved Problems in Number Theory, Section D3.
W. Ljunggren, A diophantine problem, J. London Math. Soc. (2), 3 (1971), p. 385-391.
links: Andrew Bremner, An equation of Mordell, Math. Comp., 29 (1975), p. 925-928.
formula: x such that 6y^2 = (x + 1)(x^2 - x + 6) has solutions in integers.
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_.
